definition: two/both/some/a few/tael, unit of weight equal to 50 grams (modern) or 1⁄16 of a catty 斤[jin1] (old)
mouth/classifier for things with mouths (people, domestic animals, cannons, wells etc)/classifier for bites or mouthfuls
variant of 人[ren2]/"person" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 10), occurring in 兒, 兀, 兄 etc
erhua variant of 小兩口|小两口[xiao3 liang3 kou3]

sentences.english: The couple now go on their honeymoon which can last several days or weeks.
sentences.chinese: 然后小两口儿去度蜜月，蜜月通常为几天或几周。

sentences.english: And then the couple goes on their honeymoon.
sentences.chinese: 然后小两口儿就去度蜜月了。

sentences.english: May you two live together till old and grey.
sentences.chinese: 愿你们两口儿白头偕老。

definition: erhua variant of 小兩口|小两口[xiao3 liang3 kou3]
I/me/my/(often used in early vernacular literature)
organizer of a gambling party who takes a cut of the winnings/banker (gambling)/preceding player (in a game)/(dialect) boss/proprietor
son-in-law (used by wife's family)/uncle (husband of father's sister)
parents of one's daughter-in-law or son-in-law/relatives by marriage
sir (respectful form of address for an old man)
